openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Vatican City is primarily sustained through the sale of stamps, coins, medals, and tourist souvenirs, as well as through fees collected from museum admissions and publication sales.
• In 2016, Vatican City employed a total of 4,822 individuals across various sectors.
• The Italian state provides subsidies to Vatican City, which include free water supply, tax exemptions, and other forms of dedicated public funding.
• Vatican City issues its own coins and stamps, maintaining a unique monetary and philatelic identity.
• Since 1 January 1999, Vatican City has used the euro as its official currency based on a special agreement with the European Union, specifically council decision 1999/98.
• Euro coins and banknotes were introduced in Vatican City on 1 January 2002; however, the Vatican does not issue euro banknotes, only coins.
• The issuance of euro-denominated coins by Vatican City is strictly limited by treaty agreements, with a slightly increased allowance during years when there is a change in the papacy.
• Vatican euro coins are considered rare and are highly sought after by collectors worldwide due to their limited issuance and unique designs.
• Examples of Vatican euro coins include those featuring images of Pope Francis and Pope Benedict XVI, reflecting the papal succession and Vatican heritage.
• In 2021, Vatican City's budget reported revenues amounting to €770 million.
• The expenditures for Vatican City in 2021 totaled €803 million.
• The resulting budget deficit for Vatican City in 2021 was €33 million.
• Key industries in Vatican City include printing, production of a small quantity of mosaics, and manufacturing of staff uniforms.
• Vatican City also engages in worldwide banking and financial activities as part of its economic operations.
• In 2010, Vatican City produced 442 megawatt-hours (MWh) of electricity from solar panels.
• The electricity supply for Vatican City is imported from Italy.
• Since 2002, Vatican City has used the euro as its official currency.
• Vatican City relies on Italy for the practical production of banknotes, stamps, and other valuable titles.
• Vatican euro coins are considered rare and are highly sought after by collectors.
• The fiscal year for Vatican City corresponds to the calendar year.
